trs: A Trumai narrative: the Smooth-billed Ani'\\
she left.'\\
She went out (of her house) taking a rope (to tie firewood), and she left.'\\

src: kaʔʃɨ    t̪'axer   lahmi=n  kaʔʃɨ   den    lahmi=n
trs: She left, she disappeared (in the distance).'\\

src: ina        hen   tsi-aɬahne  de kaʔʃɨ   den     lahmi hen
trs: His poor grandmother went walking and disappeared.'\\
Then he went (to her house) and started lying. He, the Smooth-billed Ani.'\\
He gathered his grandmother's firewood and put it in a hammock.'\\
Very perfectly, he put in the hammock a thing imitating a human foot, and (another) thing imitating a human head.'\\
He was pretending (that his grandmother had died).'\\

src: inis          hen   tsile         iji          ora=n        ale
trs: Then he cried:
Then he broke all of his grandmother's things: \textit{too}!'\\
He broke little clay pans, the basket with her red body paint, the basket for wax.'\\

imt: well    well   really/very  hearsay   \textsc{prag.in} break   break
src: det̪'a  det̪'a pits             tsile         iji         mapa   mapa
trs: He broke (everything) very well.'\\
He broke and burned all of his grandmother's things.'\\

src: ina           iji          ora   muketsi=n            ale          hen
trs: Then, he kept crying.'\\

src: huk'anik    huta.kaʃ   ka      a       huʔtsa  kawa
trs: “Wait, later we are going to see her (i.e., take care of her)."'\\

src: ka      ana=k        t̪'axe-t̪'axer  ji          hupda.hupekawa=n  kale
trs: “We will cry for her, poor her," his aunt said like this.'\\
I misled the wretched dog.'\\
I misled it, the wretched one.'\\
I pulled Makarea's shirt.'\\

src: in  ka.in t̪'axe-t̪'axer ji ora muketsi=n
trs: “He is there, crying" (his aunt said).'\\
“You see, you poor thing?!"'\\
“You always complain about your grandmother (but now she is gone)," his aunt said.'\\

src: sift̪'a    ji   de	 etsi lako=ktsi  ke
trs: There (she was), she was bringing wood.'\\
She was coming back.'\\
Then she heard her grandson (the Smooth-billed Ani) weeping:'\\

imt: well  well  really/very  hearsay  cry=\textsc{3abs}  hearsay
src: det̪'a  det̪'a  pits  tsile ora=n  ale
trs: With great attention, he cried (and by doing so, he invented the crying for mourning someone's death).'\\

src: niʔde  adis-pa wan  ora   le  de  in
trs: all these Indians cry (like that).'\\
They cry using his way of crying.'\\
(He was doing it) very well.'\\
His grandmother was already coming: \textit{tɨk}!'\\
“Is this bastard lying?" (she said).'\\
She arrived throwing (her wood) on the floor: \textit{pookal}!'\\
The moment his grandmother entered there (in her house), he immediately left running.'\\

src: endenʃe it̪a iji  ora  tsuketsi=n  ale
trs: Crying, he went straight to an island in the river.'\\
“Will this bastard keep lying?" (his grandmother said).'\\

imt: \textsc{disc.con}  then   \textsc{3poss(kin)}-grandmother  pitiful=\textsc{erg}  hammock  poor    untie=\textsc{3abs}  hearsay
src: ina hen  tsi-aɬahne de=k  kaʔsa t̪'axer pupe=n ale
trs: Then his grandmother untied her poor hammock,'\\

src: inaɬ=kat̪e  sopʃat̪  t̪'axer  pat̪a.pat̪a  le  hen
trs: (took) the wood out and placed it (on the floor).'\\

src: ina hen aj de iji  kuʔku=kma=n ale
trs: He had broken everything.'\\

imt: belongings poor break break=result.of=\textsc{dat} clay.pan  small
src: faʃt̪a t̪'axer mapa mapa=t̪'a=ɬ aɬat̪ pat
trs: Then his grandmother went and saw the broken pieces of her things, the little clay pans ...'\\

src: det̪'a  det̪'a pits t̪'axe-t̪'axer ji  kuʔku=kma=n ale
trs: The bastard had broken everything.'\\

imt: \textsc{disc.con}  then  hearsay  then  lie      poorly=\textsc{3abs}  hearsay
src: ina hen tsile  hen tsula  t̪'axer=e  ale
trs: Then she lay down, sad (thinking about her things).'\\
That's it (the story is over).'\\
